positive.review:
I never thought that out of all the games, a racing sim is the one I'd have the most success getting my friends to play together. I always figured it would be something more mainstream and casual. Instead, it is Automobilista 2.

I have thought about this a lot, and I think there are many factors that contribute to it, For example, it is super easy to host a multiplayer lobby for friends to join and AI opponents to race against (which not all racing games/sims have). I often set this up with a good mix of settings for different skill and experience levels:

[list]
  [*] Fuel consumption, tire wear, and damage enabled, but with damage scaled down and without random mechanical failures or the ability to destroy the car to the point of being completely undrivable.
  [*] A qualifying session before the race starts, which gives everyone time to feel more comfortable in the car and track.
  [*] A multiclass race with a range of cars that match the skills and interests of all the participants. For new players, I'll often include the modern Mini Coopers, as they are more forgiving while still being fast and fun. Up to 10 classes are allowed, upping the variety (and allowing for sillier combinations) while allowing me to make sure that non-DLC cars are always available.
  [*] Any track we want, because only the host needs to own DLC tracks in order to race them in multiplayer.
  [*] I'll pick different time/day and weather settings between the qualifying and race sessions, to keep things more dynamic, and have the track set to dynamically rubber in as we drive.
  [*] Penalties on, but with full course yellows disabled.
[/list]

The result is some [b]friendly, casual racing that we can all enjoy[/b]. We all have potential to race among ourselves or AI. Those who enjoy the greater simulation and detail can experience it, and those with less experience are given a chance to learn things and aren't punished as hard. Nobody needs to own DLC except for me, but owning the DLC cars provides more variety. 

At the same time, I have the option of making the lobby less casual if I expect that I'll be getting an exclusively more experienced audience. Or I can make it more casual/silly by loading up a dirt track with Opalas and Copa Trucks, turning off penalties, and agreeing that it is okay to race dirty for this session.

[h2]Racing against the AI[/h2]

The AI is not perfect, but it races the most like humans of any racing AI I have ever seen. It can get defensive, fight for opportunities to pass, make mistakes (especially when under pressure), won't just give players space like in many racing games/sims (unless if their aggression is lowered), have individual skill levels in different situations, etc.

In our casual lobbies, depending on how I set the AI, many of us may be fighting for positions with AI in faster or slower classes, which means that everyone has a chance to race against something. In single player, the AI is amazing if tuned to your individual skill level, so that you are hitting around average lap times.

[h2]Simulation depth and controls[/h2]

The realism of the physics is always debated, but the physics are detailed, the cars' features and behaviors are well modeled, weather simulation is among the best, and the controls are good enough (across the range from a fancy force feedback wheel to a Steam Deck). I'm happy with this as it is.

Lots of my friends play on a basic controller, and this works well enough. A bunch of us are using various force feedback wheels. Not that I'd recommend it, but one of my friends consistently races on keyboard and can be competitive within our group!

[h2]Content[/h2]

Automobilista 2 (or AMS2, as it is often referred to) has a ton of base game cars and tracks. It is especially cool that many lesser known (often Brazilian) tracks and series lend a ton of variety that aren't easily found in other games/sims. Owning the DLC is definitely not necessary to have fun, and the base game has a ridiculous amount of value.

At the same time, the DLC is priced decently compared to other racing sims and generally adds a lot of variety and good quality content. Buying DLC may be necessary if you only care about particular (and often popular) cars and tracks. I said it before, but [b]owning DLC tracks is not necessary to race on the DLC tracks when joining a multiplayer lobby[/b], as long as the host owns them, which is such a consumer-friendly choice.

There aren't a ton of road cars, as AMS2 is largely focused on motorsport. There [i]is[/i] a good amount of representation when looking at open wheel (17 classes for different F1 seasons!), GT, endurance racing prototypes, historic, etc. cars. I do think that touring cars are a bit of a gap in the roster. Not everything is officially licensed, but this does not bother me and you can always find skin packs published by the community.

[h2]Improvements over time[/h2]

I appreciate that AMS2 has continued to improve with tweaks to the physics, AI, UI, multiplayer networking, force feedback, etc. over time. Besides the stream of DLC releases, there are sometimes additions or updates to the base game or previously released DLC. These continued commitments to improving the game make it easier to recommend.

I wouldn't recommend buying it for this before the feature is released, but a career mode has always been in the plans and is expected in 2026. Part of the idea with all of the content additions has been to flesh out all of the different paths you could take in the career.

[h2]Virtual Reality[/h2]

AMS2 is considered one of the best racing games for VR. Besides everything which isn't VR-specific, the balance it strikes between performance and graphical fidelity really lends itself well to VR, and it has decent UI/UX both in the menus and when racing.

Most of my time in AMS2 has been in VR, and it makes it hard to go back to racing sims that don't have VR support that works or performs at the same level.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2] 

You may be able to find friendly and competitive races online, especially if joining a league and/or using a third party service (like LFM), but this isn't my focus or where AMS2 stands out the most. If you must have a full roster of officially licensed cars in some particular class, you may be disappointed. These aren't the reasons to get the game.

It is easy for me to recommend Automobilista 2 to any who may have interest in racing. Racing with friends or in single player (with AI in the mix either way) are where it really shines. In these cases, it is easy to tailor the experience as you like. There is a ton of content and variety, especially for the price, especially when on sale. I've had many friends get into AMS2 who previously thought they could never enjoy a sim racing game.

Note that when playing on Linux, you will need to explicitly force it to use Proton, or else the game won't run, because the game has been misconfigured in Steam.

Most photo realistic racing sim I’ve ever played.

Automobilista 2 is criminally underrated. The way this game looks in motion is insane - lighting, reflections, track detail, weather transitions… sometimes it genuinely feels like I’m watching real onboard footage, not playing a game. Night racing in the rain, headlights, reflections in the mirrors - pure madness. And yes, it has full native triple screen support - triples work exactly as they should, no hacks, no pain, the immersion is on a whole different level.

Car handling is insanely satisfying: you feel the weight transfer, the moment when grip starts to go, the car dancing on the edge. Every class has its own character - from old-school classics to modern GTs – nothing feels copy-paste, all the cars feel alive. The sounds are brutal too: engines scream, shifts punch, curbs and bumps are all there in your hands and ears.

There’s a ton of content: lots of unique Brazilian tracks you don’t see in other sims, legendary circuits, different eras of cars… you can sink hundreds of hours into this and still find something new.

If you love sim racing and want a game that looks almost like real life and drives amazingly well, Automobilista 2 is an absolute must-have. This game is fucking awesome.

AMS2.. where to start. Well this was my first driving sim I purchased on steam and one of the main reason's for creating a steam account. For a still in development game continuously being updated the $25 for the base game content which is a huge amount is well worth it. Really good value for money and easy to jump on to play with friends or offline against AI. Starting off playing many hours on controller(X360) before eventually getting a wheel(Moza R3) I can say it was still playable and enjoyable on controller with the assists all turned off(if I played on controller ever again I would just use them) . In saying that there are some players on the time trial leaderboards in the top10 on controller but for actual racing it's not consistent enough. Catching slides without losing too much momentum and other small corrections cost a lot more time on controller and you will not have consistent lap times in anything but really slow cars or assisted cars on very select tracks. Catching a slide the traditional way by counter steering then turning back into the corner inducing understeer like you need to do in openwheelers constantly is impossible without a wheel unless you are a precision controller player.. which are a few and far between.

I should mention at this point the hardware I am running or have run:
i7 6700 24GB of DDR3 Ram and GTX 1060 it handled nearly everything apart from the odd framepacing issue/stutter in certain areas of tracks with a lot of cars playing online when league raicng.
I have upgraded to a 7500f Ryzen 5 system running 32GB DDR5 and currently a 1660Ti which runs even smoother then the old system and also allows a max extended grid which the old cpu struggled with. Gfx settings are still set very similar to the 1060 was so it can maintain a stable 138fps with freesync and 144Hz refresh rate. Have had no stutters on this setup yet.
Controller wise I started with my old faithful Xbox360 controller and moved on to a Moza R3 bundle with the SRP Lite pedals with an added shock absorber and reduced travel on the throttle which is very nice to use in this game with it's throttle torque mapping being fairly realistic. The direct drive wheel allows freedom to test different custom ffb configs to find something that works for you since ffb is very subjective. I prefer a more pure direct steering rack forces type of ffb vs having extra 'canned' fx.

The actual driving itself has come a long long way from when I first got the game and it seemed every car was very happy to leave any corner in a massive powerslide, That was also the fastest way round most corners. One thing I'm not completely sure on is whether this game is aiming to continue making the game more realistic as the differential modelling, throttle torque mapping and tire model are in a decent place with just tweaks to try remove that project cars 2 feel from the game still coming one by one, The floatiness is still there particularly some of the GT3 cars(BMW gen 1...) and it does drive a lot faster lap time wise then other sims and irl. The good parts are cars that can be a bit too powerful and hard to get near the limit like f1 cars are quite accessible in this and the handling model works really nicely for older formula one cars and open wheelers in general. The open wheelers showcase the superior tire model this game has to it's predecessor where the tire actually has some flex in it and progressive loss of grip. These are my favourite cars to drive by far in this game alongside some of the touring cars and other lower powered gems. 
Getting a custom ffb file can completely change the experience and finding a good custom file will go a long way with how much you enjoy this game when you start pushing for the absolute limits. I hold rF2 as the gold standard in ffb and I have not quite been able to get that same feeling when the brakes are on to the point the car is squirreling around on the rear tires and feeling the fronts load up like it happens in real life but it has definitely improved.  

The game is definitely a much friendlier intro to any driving games more on the sim then arcade side of the spectrum. Using the assists and other controller settings it's playable for nearly anyone, much like AMS1 it has a unique selection of brazilian content, great amount of base content and plenty of dlc to expand with more cars and tracks once the base game isn't enough. I purchased all available dlc after playing for 3 or 4mo but have some more to now get that has been released in the meantime. This is purely to support further development on the game as I believe it still has more potential especially if a dedicated server was available. Latest online play on the day of this review netcode did seem better then the last time I had played online over 6mo before this review date. So online seems to be more stable compared to 6months ago in other words. Most leagues I believe are hosting on JustRace or I assume some use LFM too which I haven't tried(daily officially hosted races or leagues etc.) as netcode had become a big issue causing lots of ruined races. The environment with full weather effects and day night cycles is a really nice aspect of offline or online races especially longer ones.

Even though the driving style may not be completely realistic it is fun, combined with the really good parts which are the performance of the game on older hardware where it really is punching above it's weight, the immersive graphics sounds and overall environment. It still requires a lot of practice to get really fast in the top classes giving plenty of content to challenge the player to master. The dev team are very active with bug fixes and constantly providing updates showing they are committed to improving this game aswell as adding new content so I can only recommend it and hope this rather long review helps someone out there. Great unique game from a great unique studio. Will stay a part of my sim rotation for a long time. A nice game to compliment the first AMS game and other titles where the AI are lacking a bit, some work still needs done on them here but they are on the whole fairly decent in the right class/track combo. The game is moddable but with other games like AMS1 or rF2 in my collection and quality/scope of vanilla content I do not bother risking the stability of the game with mods.

In a nutshell the game is good for offline and social racing but anything semi competitive it falls apart from a combination of poor online stability and the floaty physics. As tires wear the physics flaws show more and more, tire pressures outside the optimum and you lose grip for no reason. Really is like the DR2.0 of circuit racing games. The good stuff is the range of classes and offline/AI play, perfect for a casual race with a few mates and some AI to bulk out the grid but not much more. I do have hope with the very advanced differential model and tire model they find a sweetspot but as time and more updates pass I have less hope..

Automobilista 2 is one of those games which just resonate with you whilst you're driving. Open wheel, endurance, GT and many more racing categories just nail that realism perfectly. The AI is fantastic, sure they might be a bit goofy at times but those can be fixed easily and the racing from them is really great. The weather is quite nice although maybe there could be a more detailed setting for customising the weather just for your own personal needs, the day and night cycle is great also though maybe the day sky should be a bit more vibrant and when it turns dusk with overcast clouds usually the sky is this dark blue-ish type colour which i find it a bit unrealistic when its slowly getting into dusk the overcast clouds are still grey. The sounds are amazing and the atmosphere really gives that immersion that you're in an actual race with all the crowds cheering, the music playing in the background and the overall environment of the track feels immersive. Graphics is also something which I wont complain about although texture wise it could be improved by a little or maybe even more because when I'm driving lets say an LMP2 car the cockpit feels too plasticity and very bold and you can really see the difference when comparing LMP2 car from lets say LMU. With car handleling  its quite alright although with some cars like the rental kart it doesn't feel heavy and it is very slippery, based on my experience driving rental karts its a little inaccurate but with other cars the handeling is quite nice. I'm glad AMS2 has been improving the game ever since the start and I'm genuinely surprised at how good the game is and how much can be added.

I would like to add I am reviewing this from the perspective of someone owning a DD wheel and Sim rig.

In terms of the physics, there are a lot of strange quirks when comes to car rotation and handling. It is extremely forgiving at the grip-limit as opposed to other sim titles. This makes the game a lot easier to drive in compared to other games. It doesn't mean that you need to drive any differently than other sims, its just that once you've pushed the vehicle into an slip condition it is very easy to correct. 

I'm not saying this is a bad thing, I'd argue that out of all the games I've played that AMS2 delivers the most fun driving experience I've had out of other sims. I just want to nip this strange elitist community in the ass really. 

AMS2 requires little to no fiddling in terms of setup, the game engine is really well optimized and the setup process for a race is incredibly easy. The AI is really well balanced and constantly being changed with each update. The amount of content offered is really impressive as well. 

I would say get the base game, and then cherry pick which DLC you are most interested in as opposed to buying it all. (Or do, I'm not your bank)

The handling on controller is really good too, there is something for everyone in this game. Its not something I can say for other sim-racing titles on the market.

The game has very diverse tracks and cars, including Formula, GT class, off-road, stock cars, and even go-karts. The car physics still feel good if you play with a gamepad. The only drawback in this game is that there's no Ford Mustang GT3, but overall, this game is worth buying.

Should you play this game called automobalista 2 – yes 

Why? – it is a very solid and polished game. I have in my experience I did not run into any game breaking bugs recently and all of the content seems to be working perfectly well. 

The good
Content wise – I have never been in a position where I have questioned what to do. But it is becoming stale and a little repetitive. The campaign should be coming soon as of writing and the devs seem to be open to criticism as they are adding different types of cars and a lot of different tracks. 

The graphics – the best I have seen for most games in the sim category. Runs on a potato and looks good doing it. I run on a moistly medium to low setting and it looks like it’s a movie most of the time. The models are brilliant, and the optimisation is peak I have been running 47 Ish car grids and have been sat at around 50 gpu utilisation stable. 60fps flat. Not real stutters because of the game. And the latency is in the negatives, there is no latency, what you see is in real time. Its great. 

The online is to be desired but the devs are working on it hopefully. The game is more singleplayer oriented as the AI is the best in any game to this day. 

In my opinion this is better the asseto Corsa. No argument, and if you disagree fight me. (or message me and I can explain further)

The ugly

Handling model – I have a Logitech g920, so the detail of the handling is lacking at most for me, so I am not going to say much. But what I will say is that they are making it better then what it was a while ago. The floaty handling is slowly going away, the ability to brake aggressively is a lot better than it was also but there is still room for improvement as is for every sim these days. 

The community, for the most part. Scaring people off because you did not like the game is the worst thing about this game. That’s all really.
That’s all I can say really. No major game breaking bugs, no massive holes of content or broken promises. The devs rock up at the start of the month, drop some great polished content and then disappear for the rest of it. Its some of the most surprising way of doing it in my opinion. And the best way to keep players sort of exited for what they drop. 

In conclusion, should you spend your hard stolen cash on this game – yes. Do you buy all of the DLC – no, buy what you want when you want and get the rest on sale. Just don’t be coming into it as demanding and get used to the handling and have fun.

Let me be perfectly clear,, this HAS the potential to be something greater than the sum of its roots(Project Cars2)((not a long stones throw i know)) .. but, after playing for a little bit(compared to other Race-Sims) the tire dynamics are just a Chef's kiss,most of the time. Kinda the "60% of the time it works every time" vibe going on.. but the flat spot dynamic and a few other concepts and features are just M'wah Chef's kiss..Plus LIVE ACTUAL WEATHER. The names are in old F1 are great and worth the price of the game, when on sale... that being said you don't get a whole lot with the base model, and DLC can get pricey. I don't want to go in on AI play as it seems that every one in the F1 sim and beyond has adopted this only in the cornering will you truly see the level of the AI...i.e. If you are a good driver, and set it to like lets say 85 and below. If you can carry that speed "in and trough" racers will catch the drift here :).. your gonna hit a lot of rear ends and rear side quat panels.. they either are moving chicanes or brake check you into next week.. now I know depending on the discipline, back-markers may not have to yield to others.. but in this they seem to either get in their own and others way, or run a screen for the AI in front of you.. plus no save to wrap it all..I do recommend and I do hope they, the Devs., continue on their Buggy Brazilian Quest to have a REALLY GOOD GAME SOON!! thnks and Enjoy
After finding a few communities on discord this is my main sim, I really like the way the car handle and react to my inputs, it feels very natural.

All the reviews and videos on YT are right, nearly everything works right out of the box with AMS2, no issues, no shutters, no mods to install or anything like that. Just load it up, set your FFB, tweak your graphics and then have fun driving anything from an old 70's box to the latest Hypercars around all sorts of circuits, and you can do it against a bunch of AI who will race you, keep you on your toes, and make you work for the position. 8/10 so far I just wish I had got it sooner when it was like $5 on sale haha.

Coming from ACC I wanted a little more variation from just GT3 so I bought this instead of PMR, so glad I did. This sim is awesome. The graphics are easily on par if not better than any more modern titles, the cars look and sound truly amazing. Works great with controller and wheel, the FFB is great, feels a lot like ACC. Also scratches the Gran turismo itch if you don't have a PS5. There's a ton of cars and tracks even in the base version so no need to spend extra on the DLC's if you don't want to but there are a couple I would pick up on sale. Highly recommend.

The best single player sim currently on the market, the car behavior is a little weird when compared to other hardcore sims but I just mean that in the way that the cars angle through corners, it still achieves an above average realism it just does it in a different way. Ive play countless sims but this one with the tyre contact focus is pretty sweet, love how the GT cars come alive, balanced and good FFB.

Not usually a review guy but this deserves one. If you're into sim racing to have fun and mess around with stuff you'd never be able to touch in real life, AMS2 and original Assetto Corsa is what you want.

Even for a large AAA industry, these devs do very impressive, high quality work. Their team is kept fairly small for good reason. I remember leaving this behind last year with updates and lack of content ongoing. Each update would cause a reset for your tunes, but I happened to distract myself with other sims in the meantime. The only regrets I had in that time was spending so much as a dime on other sims like ACC and iRacing.

This is the only sim out there that can make sense with physics and it's effects with the mass of your vehicle. A Porsche will be Rear engine for example so you want tighter springs to compensate with the proper reactions of pumps and undulations on track. This rightly reflects onto tire temps, and wear and is the only sim I know of to do this correctly!
Online racing is almost dead unfortunately, but I hope that changes soon. There's still a lot of small, but important improvements made by devs just recently. I can't help but notice how polished this game really is on top of so many tracks. I'm able to keep max graphics in 4k and run a solid 120 fps with 50 AI drivers on track. And the AI really shines when you give a chance to train them, you might find them to be very self aware. The devs know there's still work to be done and I can trust them with their future ambitions.

I like it I just think it would be funny to give a negative review with over 1200 hours on the game.
alright racing game, but you guys have time to pump out hundred of dollars of DLC but you can't implement a career mode? god knows IF it ever comes, it'll be DLC too lol.

Lack of Career Mode is huge issue. Especially if there is Career Mode button in main menu and it's grayed out! If I knew it then I wouldn't be interesten in this game at all.
All my favourite tracks are gone and got released as DLC. Instead they brought a lot of Brazilian tracks which I'm not interested into. I'd consider buying DLC but if game would include Career Mode.
The reason why Career Mode is so important for me is it's just great introduction to the game. You learn about mechanics and still have feeling you improve more than just repeating custom races. It's just souless.
Real fun of course begins with multiplayer mode but I'd rather go through at least a little bit ambitious single player mode before I will get ready for multiplayer.

Big time Gran Turismo fan here.  This game has decent graphics, however the collision and weight distribution/steering physics are garbage.  car slides around, even with adequate braking.  if another car is thinking about touching you then you lose the ability to steer through a turn.  lastly, if you collide with a vehicle they just bounce around the track like they weigh nothing.  even at half price, i am likely going to request my money back and return this heap.  deciding factor/big red flag for me, the game is 5 years old, yet career mode has still not been developed.

The Devs have been promising a career mode since 2020, 5 years later and they still do not have a career mode.

There is over 100$ USD in DLC but no career mode...

Every time they drop an update I have issues with my wheel and pedals and have to spend waaay too much time re- configuring  everything,  I like to be able to jump in when I have the time and start racing, not troubleshoot for hours. 
WHEN I can get the game to work properly with my Logitech G Pro setup the game is great but having to go through so much BS to get there is not worth my time anymore.  I never have any issues with other games like Assetto Corsa (OG) , Dirt Rally 2.0 , EA WRC, Forza Motorsport, they are all good, but this game always seems to screw everything up every time they update it.

I hate it, I want to love this game so much. The DLC content historic and current cars and tracks is amazing and better than in any other game. However I cannot get a feel for the cars at all. It feels like im drifting non stop and cannot tell where the grip is compared to other racing titles. I don't know if this is a controller specific thing but its a huge shame.

I want to love this game because it has a lot of cars and tracks with decent graphics and sound, but the physics are weird and the force feedback doesn’t give me enough information on how I should drive. I’m not getting the same level of pleasure and satisfaction as I get in iRacing or Assetto Corsa.

The graphics are great. VR is fantastic. But what kills me is the physics. They are so unbelievably terrible. It feels like I'm driving on snow and ice the entire time. Rain physics is what does it for me. By far the worst I've played since Bayou Billy on the Sega Genesis. I'd love to give this game a second shot if they improve the physics in future updates.
